{{Infobox person | name = Patrick Courrielche | image = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[California]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | nationality = [[Hispanic]] | other_names = | occupation = media [[entrepreneur]] | alma_mater = [[University of California, Los Angeles]] | known_for = [[Pop-up retail]], [[Citizen Journalism]] | spouse = Adryana Courrielche | homepage = [http://www.inform-ventures.com/ www.inform-ventures.com] | imagesize = }}
'''Patrick Courrielche''' is an American media entrepreneur, writer, arts advocate, and [[political pundit]], known for pioneering the [[pop-up retail]] trend.<ref name="business2community.com">Swystun, Jeff, (September 1, 2015) Business 2 Community. "Pop-Up Retail: Where Will It Go Next?" http://www.business2community.com/branding/pop-retail-will-go-next-01316364#O8D30UjGdcgSH2Io.97</ref>He has written articles for and appeared on a variety of media outlets.<ref name="video.foxbusiness.com">Varney, Stuart, (August 27, 2009) Fox Business. "Where's YOUR Tax Money Going?" http://video.foxbusiness.com/v/3894796/wheres-your-tax-money-going/?#sp=show-clips</ref><ref name="youtube.com">Sanchez, Rick, (October 23, 2009) CNN. "Hollywood's New Bandwagon" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gyd4a3-QMlM</ref><ref>Courrielche, Patrick, (August 7, 2009) Reason.com. "The Artist Formerly Known as Dissident" http://reason.com/archives/2009/08/07/the-artist-formerly-known-as-d</ref><ref>Courrielche, Patrick, (December 21, 2015) The Daily Caller. "St. Nicholas: The Birth Of A Social Weapon." http://dailycaller.com/2015/12/21/st-nicholas-the-birth-of-a-social-weapon/</ref> His writing has led to the White House issuing new federal guidelines, and the international music industry suing a website for copyright infringement.<ref name="blogs.abcnews.com">Tapper, Jake, (September 22, 2009) ABCNews.com. "After 'Inappropriate' NEA Conference Call, White House Pushes New Guidelines" {{cite web |url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2009/09/after-inappropriate-nea-conference-call-white-house-pushes-new-guidelines.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150711225650/http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2009/09/after-inappropriate-nea-conference-call-white-house-pushes-new-guidelines.html |archivedate=2015-07-11 |df= }}</ref><ref>RIAA News (September 26, 2016) RIAA.com. "IFPI: WORLD'S LARGEST MUSIC STREAM RIPPING SITE FACES INTERNATIONAL LEGAL ACTION" https://www.riaa.com/ifpi-worlds-largest-music-stream-ripping-site-faces-international-legal-action/</ref>
== Career == While working as an applied physicist for aerospace firm [[TRW Inc.]], in 1997 Courrielche started the now ubiquitous pop-up retail trend - or short-term sales spaces - with an event called the Ritual Expo. Initially a nightclub-meets-shopping experience, the event would eventually focus solely on creating temporary shopping experiences during the day and was initially called the "ultimate hipster mall." The event was known for attracting style brokers and cultural influencers in Los Angeles.<ref>Romero, D. James, (April 24, 1997) Los Angeles Times. "Ritual" http://articles.latimes.com/1997-04-24/news/ls-51710_1_fashion-labels</ref><ref>Jones, Rose Apodaca, (August 28, 2000) WWD. "Cool Like That" http://wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-features/article-1198580/</ref><ref>Baltin, Steve, (October, 2000) Chicago Tribune. "Ritual in the Making, Creative Fields Converge To Form Ultimate Hipster Mall In A Nightclub Atmosphere." http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2000-10-11/features/0010100545_1_jed-wexler-ritual-events-walk</ref><ref>Moore, Booth, (July, 1999) LA Times. "Cutting-Edge Clothes and Music at Ritual Expos." http://articles.latimes.com/1999/jul/09/news/cl-54193</ref> According to Courrielche, he started his pop-up retail stores with smaller, hard-to-find clothing manufacturers because large corporate brands did not immediately find value in the new concept. That all changed with the 2000 publication of [[The Tipping Point]] by [[Malcolm Gladwell]]. In his book, Gladwell emphasized the importance of connecting with "influencers" to sell a product or service. Companies began contacting Courrielche to create pop-up stores to reach these influencers, and he eventually sold the Ritual Expo to the creators of [[Lollapalooza]] and began working with [[Levi Strauss]], [[AT&T]], and [[Motorola]] to execute pop-up retail stores all across the US that featured their products alongside smaller fashion brands and artworks by [[Shepard Fairey]] and [[Dave Kinsey]]. Courrielche is now referred to as "the parent of pop up."<ref name="business2community.com"/><ref>Video compilation of some of first pop-up retail stores. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lsX0f7526Zc</ref>
In 1998, Courrielche started a lifestyle marketing & PR firm, Inform Ventures, with his future wife Adryana Courrielche, and in 2003 began work with [[Toyota]] launching its new youth brand [[Scion (automobile)|Scion]] – considered culturally significant for its use of the arts in attracting customers. He handled Scion's public relations and promotions during the launch, created and produced several branded-entertainment films, including a 2004 docudrama featuring [[Questlove]] from [[The Roots]] and a 2007 short-film featuring [[Biz Markie]], and in 2005 helped create and launch [[Scion Audio/Visual]] - one of the first brand-funded record labels.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oxQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA57&lpg=PA57&dq=courrielche+scion&source=bl&ots=maoh7NESwB&sig=hNZSa9A9n9Jr94QvlI2DvX5O394&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjg-oruj8HNAhUH5mMKHVjzAQ04ChDoAQgyMAE#v=onepage&q=toyota's%20scion%20starts%20label&f=false |title=Toyota's Scion Starts Label |publisher=‘’Billboard’’ |date=March 26, 2005 |accessdate=June 24, 2016}}</ref><ref>Parpis, Eleftheria, (May 17, 2004) Adweek. "Now Playing." http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising/now-playing-72490</ref><ref>Halliday, Jean, (February 28, 2007) Ad Age. "Scion Rolls Out Second Branded Film." http://adage.com/article/madisonvine-news/scion-rolls-branded-film/115238/</ref> The launch was highlighted as "the most successful automotive brand launch in the history of the auto industry of North America," with several books and researchers publishing analysis on the launch for its novel approach.<ref name="books.google.com">Walker, Rob (2010) "Buying In: The Secret Dialogue Between What We Buy and Who We Are." https://books.google.com/books?id=o8Z_qq9xjs8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=courrielche&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj89OOBiMTNAhVCy2MKHXZRCok4ChDoAQhCMAg#v=onepage&q=inform%20ventures&f=false</ref><ref>Rayport, Jeffrey, (November 20, 2008) Ad Age. "Scion's Marketing Story: As You've Never Heard it Before." https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zB9fh3JfYE4</ref><ref>Halliday, Jean, (November 8, 2004) Automotive News. "Scion builds buzz with event marketing" http://www.autonews.com/article/20041108/SUB/411080711/scion-builds-buzz-with-event-marketing</ref><ref>Halliday, Jean, (May 3, 2004) Automotive News. "Scions are co-stars at Tribeca film fest" http://www.autonews.com/article/20040503/SUB/405030722/scions-are-co-stars-at-tribeca-film-fest</ref>
Along with his wife and business partner Adryana, Courrielche created, produced, and wrote a semi-scripted 2010 series of global warming debates between global warming proponents and skeptics, and moderated by comedians [[Sarah Silverman]], [[Andy Samberg]], [[Jamie Kennedy]], [[Tracy Morgan]], and singer [[Mark McGrath]].<ref>Johnson, Ted (July 31, 2010) Variety. "Lexus drives global warming debate." https://variety.com/2010/film/news/lexus-drives-global-warming-debate-1118022395/</ref><ref>Stenquist, Paul (July 7, 2010) New York Times. "Lexus Takes Its Comedy-Fueled Debate Series on the Road." http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/07/07/lexus-takes-its-comedy-fueled-debate-series-on-the-road/</ref><ref>Mcintire-Strasburg, Jeff, (July 7, 2010) Sundance TV blog. "How to promote your new hybrid car: Host a global warming debate" http://www.sundance.tv/blog/2010/07/global-warming-debate-lexus-hybrid</ref>
In 2012, he created the first luxury automotive publicity campaign featuring a gay married couple, [[Simon Doonan]] and [[Jonathan Adler]].<ref>Greenberg, Karl (July 27, 2012) Mediapost. "For Debut, Lexus LS Poses With Celebrity Couples." http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/179644/for-debut-lexus-ls-poses-with-celebrity-couples.html</ref><ref>Read, Richard (July 31, 2012) GayWheels. "2013 Lexus LS Campaign Taps Power Couple Jonathan Adler & Simon Doonan." http://gaywheels.com/2012/07/2013-lexus-ls-campaign-taps-power-couple-jonathan-adler-simon-doonan/</ref>
== Writing == In August 2009, Courrielche participated in and secretly recorded a [[National Endowment for the Arts]] (NEA) conference call in which the NEA's communications director, Yosi Sergant encouraged the participants (members of the media and arts community) to support the [[Obama administration]]'s goals by promoting the ''United We Serve'' campaign and create art specific to areas of health care, education and the environment.<ref name="blogs.abcnews.com"/> The [[White House Office of Public Engagement]] also participated in the call.<ref name="blogs.abcnews.com"/> Courrielche criticized the NEA in a subsequent [[Breitbart News]] piece (which was published in part by the [[Wall Street Journal]]), expressing the view that the NEA was being inappropriately used for political purposes.<ref>Patrick Courrielche, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203706604574378753571636982 The National Endowment for the Art of Persuasion?], '' Wall Street Journal'' (August 25, 2009).</ref> Eleven Republican [[U.S. Senators]] criticized the conference call and questioned its legality.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2009/09/more-than-one-fifth-of-the-us-senate-all-11-of-them-republicans-is-now-on-record-as-being-alarmed-that-the-nea-has-turned.html |title=10 more GOP senators demand answers from the NEA about teleconference |newspaper= Los Angeles Times |date= September 25, 2009 |accessdate= June 24, 2016}}</ref> [[Melanie Sloan]] of the ethics group [[Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington]] said that the NEA's call was "terrible" and "inappropriate" although not a violation of federal law.<ref name="blogs.abcnews.com"/> Following the affair, Sergant resigned his position and the White House issued formal guidance and training for staffers "to make sure such a call never happens again."<ref name="blogs.abcnews.com"/><ref>Gregory Craig & Norman Eisen (September 22, 2009), The White House. "Memorandum For White House Staff and For Agency and Department Heads - Guidelines For Public Outreach Meetings" https://www.whitehouse.gov/assets/documents/WH_COUNSEL_MEMO_GUIDELINES_FOR_PUBLIC_OUTREACH_MEETINGS.pdf</ref><ref>Zeleny, Jeff (September 22, 2009) New York Times. "Agencies Instructed to Separate Politics From Grant Awards." https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/23/us/politics/23grants.html?_r=1</ref> In a 2017 op-ed in the 'Wall Street Journal', Courrielche advocated for the elimination of the NEA, claiming that it had become politically tainted, failed to meet its charter, had allowed the degradation of arts education in public schools, and was unable to meet the arts modern challenges. He suggested replacing the agency with an arts counsel that would continue necessary programs, while advising the President on legislation that he says could address what he perceives as systemic problems prohibiting it from flourishing.<ref>Courrielche, Patrick, (January 25, 2017) The Wall Street Journal. "Save the Arts by Ending the Endowment" https://www.wsj.com/articles/save-the-arts-by-ending-the-endowment-1485390654</ref>
Courrielche is active in the [[climate change]] movement.<ref>[[Fred Pearce]], [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/feb/09/climate-emails-pr-disaster-peer-review 'Climategate' was PR disaster that could bring healthy reform of peer review], ''Wall Street Journalist'' (February 9, 2010).</ref> He participated in the investigation of [[Climatic Research Unit email controversy]] ("Climategate") at the [[University of East Anglia]],<ref>Fred Pearce, [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/feb/09/hacked-emails-police-investigation Search for hacker may lead police back to East Anglia's climate research unit], ''The Guardian'' (February 9, 2010).</ref> and claimed that the affair "triggered the death of unconditional trust in the scientific peer-review process, and the maturing of a new movement of peer-to-peer review."<ref>Brian Trench, "Scientists' Blogs: Glimpses Behind the Scenes" in ''The Sciences' Media Connection –Public Communication and its Repercussions'' (eds. Simone Rödder, Martina Franzen & Peter Weingart), p. 278.</ref><ref>Fred Pearce, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=3jxSAQAAIAAJ The Climate Files: The Battle for the Truth about Global Warming]'' ([[Guardian Books]], 2010).</ref>
In 2015, Courrielche wrote a long form story "St. Nicholas: The Birth Of A Social Weapon" on the origin of Santa Claus and introduced the concept of a "social weapon" - a packaged idea, message, or product that is used by an individual or group to advance their cause. Courrielche argued that New York City elites crafted Santa Claus from St. Nicholas, a widely known patron saint, to stabilize a city plagued by annual misbehavior every December. Santa Claus was then used as a "social weapon" by merchants, craftsman, city rulers, parents, newspapers, and others to benefit their endeavors.<ref>Courrielche, Patrick (December 21, 2015) The Daily Caller. "St. Nicholas: The Birth of a Social Weapon" http://dailycaller.com/2015/12/21/st-nicholas-the-birth-of-a-social-weapon/</ref> The essay was added to the St. Nicholas Center's resource on the Origin of Santa Claus.<ref>St. Nicholas Center "St. Nicholas and the Origin of Santa Claus" http://www.stnicholascenter.org/pages/origin-of-santa/</ref>
On August 3, 2016, Courrielche published a long form story entitled "Stream Ripping: How Google/YouTube Is Slowly Killing the Music Industry" that looked at a growing trend of alleged "music piracy" enabled by stream ripping sites - websites that rip audio from streaming music sites like [[YouTube]] - that was slowly killing the business of selling songs. The story featured [[YouTube-mp3.org]] - what Courrielche called the most highly trafficked stream ripping website in the world - and followed its founder [[Philip Matesanz]] in his creation of the site as well as his early conflicts with YouTube and its parent, [[Google]]. By tracking the former and current success of [[USA for Africa]] and it's famed song [[We Are The World]], the investigation showed how the music industry was being negatively affected by stream ripping sites like YouTube-mp3.org and highlighted how YouTube-mp3.org and Google profit from the practice of stream ripping through advertising. "After a short visit to YouTube-mp3.org, 'We Are The World' can be downloaded for free," wrote Courrielche. "USA for Africa receives nothing. The stream ripping site eventually agreed to shutdown after being sued by major record labels.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/tech/2017/9/4/16252348/youtube-mp3-org-shut-down|title=Major YouTube audio-ripping site agrees to shut down after getting sued by labels|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref>

page.title: Prostitution in the United Arab Emirates

revision.comment: minor fixes
revision.text:
'''Prostitution in the United Arab Emirates''' is illegal<ref>{{cite web|title=The Legal Status of Prostitution by Country|url=http://chartsbin.com/view/snb|website=ChartsBin|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="procon">{{cite web|title=100 Countries and Their Prostitution Policies|url=https://prostitution.procon.org/view.resource.php?resourceID=000772|website=Procon|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> both under federal law<ref name="ency">{{cite book|editor1-last=Ditmore|editor1-first=Melissa Hope|title=Encyclopedia of prostitution and sex work|date=2006|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, Conn.|isbn=978-0313329685}}</ref> and [[Sharia]].<ref name="state15">{{cite web|title=Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2015|url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/253163.pdf|publisher=United States Department of State • Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> Punishments can be severe including imprisonment and [[flogging]],<ref name="procon" /> and the Sharia courts may impose more severe punishments during [[Ramadan]].<ref name="state15" /> Foreign [[prostitutes]] are deported after serving their sentences.<ref name="khalee">{{cite web|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/nation/crime/uae-has-strict-rules-against-prostitution|title=UAE has strict rules against prostitution - Khaleej Times|first=Amira|last=Agarib|publisher=|accessdate=21 March 2017}}</ref> In 2006 the UAE deported 4,300 foreign prostitutes.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Presse|first1=France|title=UAE Deports 4,300 Prostitutes|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/295954|website=Arab News|accessdate=14 December 2017|date=16 March 2007}}</ref>
Despite its illegality, [[prostitution]] is widespread, especially in [[Dubai]]<ref name="guardian">{{cite news|title= Why Dubai's Islamic austerity is a sham – sex is for sale in every bar |work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2010-05-16|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/16/dubai-sex-tourism-prostitution|accessdate=2012-04-13|location=London|first=William|last=Butler}}</ref><ref name="herald">{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/dubai-in-united-arab-emirates-an-epicentre-of-human-trafficking-and-prostitution-20160115-gm6mdl.html|title=Dubai in United Arab Emirates a centre of human trafficking and prostitution|first=Thessa|last=Lageman|date=20 January 2016|publisher=|accessdate=21 March 2017|via=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> and [[Abu Dhabi]].<ref name="herald" /><ref name="national">{{cite web|last1=Dajani|first1=Haneen Dajani|last2=Al Subaihi|title=Abu Dhabi residents complain of continued harassment from 'street escorts'|url=https://www.thenational.ae/uae/abu-dhabi-residents-complain-of-continued-harassment-from-street-escorts-1.146634|website=The National|accessdate=14 December 2017|date=22 August 2016}}</ref> The authorities generally turn a blind eye provided it is kept out of the public eye.<ref name="guardian" /> There are however, occasional clampdowns.
UAE nationals are permitted a number of residence visas. These are mainly used for domestic staff, but any surplus are often sold through middlemen to prostitutes to enter and remain in the country for two years. Residence visas may change hands at upwards of £5,000.<ref name="guardian" /> Despite a law forbidding entry to unaccompanied females under 31 years of age,<ref name="ency" /> "agents arrange for prostitutes to enter the country on a 30 day tourist visa.<ref name="guardian" />
Although there is some [[street prostitution]], notably Hamdan Street in Abu Dhabi,<ref name="national" /> most prostitution takes place in the bars and nightclubs of hotels.<ref name="guardian" /><ref name="herald" />
==Dubai== There has been a sex trade in Dubai for many years. In 1936, [[Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum|Sheikh Saeed]]'s ''wali'' forced the prostitutes to get married or to leave.<ref name="dubai">{{cite book|last1=Krane|first1=Jim|title=Dubai: The Story of the World's Fastest City|date=1 December 2009|publisher=Atlantic Books|isbn=978-1782397601|url=https://books.google.com/?id=1pbOYuGWKJgC&pg=PT131&lpg=PT131&dq=1950%27s+%26+1960%27s,+two+madams+controlled+the+prostitutes+in+dubai#v=onepage&q=1950's%20%26%201960's%2C%20two%20madams%20controlled%20the%20prostitutes%20in%20dubai&f=false}}</ref> During the 1950's & 1960's, two madams controlled the [[Iran|Iranian]] prostitutes. One controlled the [[red-light district]] in [[Bur Dubai]], the other around Nasser Square (now Baniyas Square).<ref name="dubai" /> [[Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum|Sheikh Rashid]] ordered that all the prostitutes were rounded up and deported. This caused a [[Bank run|run]] on the local British bank when the women tried to draw out all their savings.<ref name="dubai" />
Modern Dubai is one of the main centres of prostitution in the UAE and is dubbed "Sodom-sur-Mer".<ref name="guardian" /> There are estimated to be 30,000 prostitutes in the city.<ref name="guardian" /><ref name="herald" /> Prostitutes frequent the bars and nightclubs in the hotels.<ref name="guardian" /><ref name="herald" /> Many prostitutes from poorer countries, such as [[Nigeria]],<ref name="nigeria">{{cite web|last1=Banjo|first1=Temi|title=Revealed: Nigerian Ladies And Prostitution In United Arab Emirates (UAE), Dubai|url=http://www.nigerianmonitor.com/revealed-nigerian-ladies-and-prostitution-in-united-arab-emirates-uae-dubai/|website=Nigerian Monitor|accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref> come to work in Dubai for a short while and then return home with their earnings.
There are also [[brothels]] in Dubai.<ref name="dubai" /> The Cyclone, near the airport<ref name="guardian" /> was closed down in 2007 after it was featured in [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] magazine,<ref name="dubai" /> but the operation simply set up at another location.<ref name="guardian" /> Known by visitors as the ''"United Nations of prostitution"'', the club have as many as 500 prostitutes on the premises on an average night, many from [[Azerbaijan]], [[Bulgaria]], [[China]], [[Russia]], [[Taiwan]], [[Tajikistan]], and [[Uzbekistan]].<ref name="chirico">{{cite web |last1=Chirico |first1=Annalisa |title=Prostitution as a matter of freedom |url=https://eprints.luiss.it/1353/1/20141211-chirico.pdf |publisher=[[Libera Università Internazionale degli Studi Sociali Guido Carli]] |accessdate=19 July 2018}}</ref>
The Cycle appeared in the 2008 [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] and [[Russell Crowe]] film [[Body of Lies (film)|Body of Lies]].<ref name="dubai" />
Human trafficking is a problem in Dubai,<ref name="guardian" /><ref name="herald" /> often Asian or Chinese gangs exploiting women from [[India]] or [[Nepal]].<ref name="guardian" />
==Sex tourism== The UAE attracts many foreign [[businessman|businessmen]] as it is slowly gaining a reputation as one of the [[Middle East]]'s [[sex tourism]] destinations.<ref name="ency" /><ref name="khalee" /><ref name="herald" /><ref name="nigeria"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weeklyblitz.net/2016/10/sex-tourism-billion-dollar-industry-part-1/|title=Sex tourism: A billion dollar industry (Part 1) - Weekly BLiTZ|date=8 October 2016|publisher=|accessdate=21 March 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009150511/http://www.weeklyblitz.net/2016/10/sex-tourism-billion-dollar-industry-part-1/|archivedate=9 October 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weeklyblitz.net/2016/10/sex-tourism-a-billion-dollar-industry-part-2/|title=Sex tourism: A billion dollar industry (Part 2) - Weekly BLiTZ|date=16 October 2016|publisher=|accessdate=21 March 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027023930/http://www.weeklyblitz.net/2016/10/sex-tourism-a-billion-dollar-industry-part-2/|archivedate=27 October 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Choudhury |first=Salah Uddin Shoaib |date=2011-08-19 |title=Removing curtains of Arab harems |url=http://www.weeklyblitz.net/1667/removing-curtains-of-arab-harems |newspaper=Weekly Blitz |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130313050940/http://www.weeklyblitz.net/1667/removing-curtains-of-arab-harems |archive-date=2013-03-13 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/rough/2007/09/dubai_sex_for_s.html|title=FRONTLINE/WORLD . Rough Cut . Dubai: Night Secrets - PBS|publisher=|accessdate=21 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/a/1053654.html|title=U.A.E.: Muslim Federation Of States Is Hub of International Prostitution|publisher=|accessdate=21 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/archives/news/19128/dubais-dirty-secret/|title=Dubai's dirty secret revealed as 30,000 hookers openly work|date=27 January 2015|publisher=|accessdate=21 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/united-arab-emirates/local-laws-and-customs|title=Local laws and customs - United Arab Emirates travel advice - GOV.UK|publisher=|accessdate=21 March 2017}}</ref> Many of them arrive regularly from the [[post-Soviet states]], [[South America]], [[Eastern Europe]], [[Far East]], [[Africa]], [[South Asia]], and other states of the [[Middle East]].<ref>[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2007/100608.htm United Arab Emirates], US Department of State: Diplomacy in Action</ref>
==Sex trafficking== {{see also|Human trafficking in the United Arab Emirates}} In 2007, the United States State Department placed the United Arab Emirates as a "[[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 2]]" in its annual Trafficking in Persons reports, meaning that it does not fully comply with the minimum standards for the elimination of trafficking but is making significant efforts to do so.<ref name="guardian" /><ref name="statedept">{{Citation| url=https://www.state.gov/g/tip/rls/tiprpt/2007/ |publisher=U.S. State Department|title=Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000: Trafficking in Persons Report 2007| date=June 2007}}</ref> The UAE is a destination and transit country for women subjected to [[sex trafficking]].<ref name="state17">{{cite web|title=United Arab Emirates 2017 Trafficking in Persons Report|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2017/271307.htm|publisher=United States Department of State • Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking Persons|accessdate=15 December 2017|date=2017}} {{PD-notice}}</ref> Some women, predominantly from Eastern Europe, Central Asia, South and Southeast Asia, East Africa, [[Iraq]], [[Iran]], and [[Morocco]], are subjected to [[forced prostitution]] in the UAE.<ref name="state17" /> In 2016, 22 cases related to sex trafficking were brought before the courts.<ref name="state17" />
==References== {{Reflist|}}
{{Asia in topic|Prostitution in}}
[[Category:Prostitution by country|United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Crime in the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Prostitution in the Middle East|United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Prostitution in Asia]]

revision.comment: {{Redirects|The Race Card||}}
revision.text:
{{For|the horse racing term|Racecard}} {{Redirects|The Race Card||}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2009}} [[File:Racist card.jpg|thumb|Literal "racist card"]]
'''Playing the race card''' is an [[idiomatic phrase]] that refers to exploitation of either [[racism|racist]] or [[anti-racist]] attitudes by accusing others of racism.
==Usage== The phrase is commonly used to allege that someone has deliberately and falsely accused another person of being a racist in order to gain some sort of advantage.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Playing the race card: Trump or joker? |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/special_report/1999/02/99/e-cyclopedia/1292973.stm |work=[[BBC News]] |date=2001-04-24 |accessdate=2008-09-09}}</ref> An example of this use of the term occurred during the [[O. J. Simpson]] [[O. J. Simpson murder case|murder trial]], when critics accused the defense of "playing the race card"<ref>{{Cite news|first=DeWayne |last=Wickham |title=Spare Cochran legacy of 'race card' label |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/opinion/columnist/wickham/2005-04-04-cochran-legacy_x.htm |work=[[USA Today]] |date=2005-04-04 |accessdate=2008-09-09}}</ref> in presenting [[Mark Fuhrman]]'s past (e.g., his recorded use of the word "[[nigger]]" in addition to his being accused of tampering with murder evidence in prior cases, as well as his use of the [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment]] to avoid potential [[self-incrimination]] upon questioning) as a reason to draw his credibility as a witness into question.
[[Stanford Law School|Stanford]] professor [[Richard Thompson Ford]] has argued that the race card can be played independent of the person making the claim, or the race in question. An example cited was the [[Hillary Clinton]] campaign's assertion that [[Barack Obama|Obama]] won the [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 2008|2008 Democratic primary]] in [[South Carolina]] due to the disproportionate number of black registered Democrats in the state, implying more racism in the general population.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Ford |first=Richard Thompson |authorlink=Richard Thompson Ford |title=The Race Card: How Bluffing About Bias Makes Race Relations Worse |url= |edition=|year=2008 |publisher=[[Farrar, Straus and Giroux]] |location=New York |isbn=978-0-374-24575-7 }}</ref>
[[George Dei]], ''[[et alia|et al.]]'', in the book ''Playing the Race Card''<ref>{{Cite book|last=Dei |first=George Jerry Sefa |authorlink= George Dei|author2=Leeno Luke Karumanchery |author3=Nisha Karumanchery-Luik |title=Playing the Race Card: Exposing White Power and Privilege |url= |edition=1st |date= January 2004 |publisher=[[Peter Lang (publishing company)|Peter Lang USA]] |location=New York |isbn=978-0-8204-6752-8 |oclc=51266234}}{{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> argue that the term itself is a [[rhetorical device]] used in an effort to devalue and minimize claims of racism.
==Malaysian politics== In February 2008, Group Chief Editor Wong Chun Wai of ''[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]'' wrote, just before the [[Malaysian general election, 2008|Malaysia general election]] came, there is an unusual degree of tolerance and flexibility in matters of race, language and religion as politicians try to woo the people. "Also, there are those who still continue to play the race card, in this age and time. At their party conferences each year, they play to the gallery by projecting themselves as the communal heroes. But during the general election, they shamelessly become the true Malaysian leaders we dream of. They greet their voters in [[Malay language|Malay]], [[English language|English]], [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]] and [[Tamil language|Tamil]]; and if they can speak all these languages fluently, they would do so."<ref>{{Cite news |first=Wong Chun |last=Wai |title=All for the sake of winning votes |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/2/10/focus/20287210&sec=focus |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=2008-02-10 |accessdate=2008-09-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604041549/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2008%2F2%2F10%2Ffocus%2F20287210&sec=focus |archivedate=2011-06-04 |df= }}</ref>
In August 2006, the [[Singapore Institute of International Affairs]] wrote that Malaysia politician [[Khairy Jamaluddin]] "played the race card" by stirring up the [[Malaysian Malay|Malays]] and the [[Chinese Malaysian]] community. Responding to criticisms and demands for an apology, Khairy said his remarks were misunderstood and he "will not apologise" as he was acting only "in defence of the Malays and his party" and that "if we truly fight for our race, one should not apologise".<ref>{{Cite web|title=Use of race card stirs controversy in Malaysia |url=http://www.siiaonline.org/page/insightsDetails/id/2014/ArticleCategoryId/7 |publisher=[[Singapore Institute of International Affairs]] |date=2006-08-29 |accessdate=2008-09-09}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Appeal to motive]] *[[Boerehaat]] *[[Identity politics]] *[[Laissez-faire racism]] *[[Wedge issue]] *[[Woman card]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Race Card}} [[Category:American English idioms]] [[Category:Racism]] [[Category:Politics and race in the United States]] [[Category:African-American-related controversies]] [[Category:Defamation]]

revision.text:
A '''Spontaneous Unaffiliated Volunteer''' (SUV) refers to individuals who volunteer to assist community members, typically after a large-scale or well-publicized [[disaster]]. Because unaffiliated volunteers lack consistent [[training]], and each volunteer's [[Trust (social sciences)|trustworthiness]] is unknown, SUV management can be very difficult, and the subject of a large amount of research and practice.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.fema.gov/pdf/donations/ManagingSpontaneousVolunteers.pdf|title = Managing Spontaneous Volunteers in Times of Disaster: The Synergy of Structure and Good Intentions|date = |access-date = January 22, 2016|website = Managing Spontaneous Unaffiliated Volunteers|publisher = FEMA|last = FEMA|first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.cert-la.com/education/disasterbook.pdf|title = Preventing a Disaster within the Disaster: The Effective Use and Management of Unaffiliated Volunteers|date = 2002|access-date = January 22, 2016|website = |publisher = Points of Light Foundation & Volunteer Center National Network|last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Managing Unaffiliated Volunteers in Times of Disaster|url = http://www.nationalservice.gov/resources/disaster-services/managing-unaffiliated-volunteers-times-disaster|website = Corporation for National and Community Service|access-date = 2016-01-23}}</ref>
In many community organizing circles, the term "Community Volunteer" is preferred, emphasizing the community-centric nature of unaffiliated [[Volunteering|volunteerism]].
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{for|the footballer of the same name|Stephen Gough (footballer)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox person |name=Stephen Gough |birth_name=Stephen Peter Gough |birth_date={{birth date and age|1959|05|13|df=y}} |birth_place=[[Southampton]], England<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.genesreunited.co.uk/search/results?sourcecategory=birthsutf002c+marriages+utf0026+deaths&collection=births+utf0026+baptisms&datasetname=england+utf0026+wales+births+1837-2006&firstname=stephen+p&lastname=gough&birthyear=1959&birthyear_offset=0&region=great+britain|title=Stephen P Gough - England & Wales Births 1837-2006 [1] - Genes Reunited|first=Genes|last=Reunited|date=|website=www.genesreunited.co.uk|accessdate=21 May 2017}}</ref> |other_names=Naked Rambler |nationality=British |occupation=[[Activist]], ex-[[lorry driver]], former [[Royal Marine]] }} '''Stephen Peter<ref>http://hudoc.echr.coe.int/app/conversion/pdf/?library=ECHR&id=003-4917111-6016584&filename=003-4917111-6016584.pdf</ref> Gough''' (born 13 May 1959),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://barristerblogger.com/published-articles-3/r-v-stephen-gough-2015-ewca-crim-1079/|title=R v. Stephen Gough [2015] EWCA Crim 1079|author=Matthew Scott|date=|website=barristerblogger.com|accessdate=21 May 2017}}</ref> popularly known as the "Naked Rambler", is a [[British people|British]] activist and former [[Royal Marine]] and prisoner of conscience.<ref name=SundayTimes-1593666/> In 2003–04, he walked the length of [[Great Britain]] naked, but was arrested when he did it again in 2005-06. Since then he has spent most of the intervening years in prison, having been repeatedly rearrested for contempt of court for [[public nudity]], each time within a short period after release. Gough stands {{convert|6| ft| 4| in|cm|abbr=on}} tall<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/7004633/The-Naked-Rambler-is-a-brazen-affront-to-the-great-undressed.html|title=The Naked Rambler is a brazen affront to the great undressed|author=William Langley|date=16 January 2010|newspaper=The Telegraph}}</ref> and has served most of his sentences in [[Saughton Prison]] and [[HM Prison Perth|Perth Prison]] in Scotland.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.vice.com/en_uk/read/naked-rambler-human-rights-246|title=Britain's Most Relentless Nudist Keeps Getting Locked Up|author=Ralph Jones|date=31 October 2014|website=Vice}}</ref>
==Activism== ===Naked rambling=== Gough, an ex-lorry driver, is from [[Eastleigh]], [[Hampshire]], and is known for walking the length of Great Britain from [[Land's End to John o' Groats]] over 2003 and 2004 wearing only boots, socks, a rucksack and sometimes a hat. He was arrested and imprisoned on numerous occasions during the course of his ramble.
His second [[Land's End]] to [[John o' Groats]] ramble was in 2005 and 2006 and accompanied by his girlfriend Melanie Roberts (born 1971 or 1972<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/what-makes-a-woman-walk-for-900-547546|title=What Makes A Woman Walk For 900 Miles In The Nude?|first=|last=|date=19 June 2005|newspaper=The Mirror}}</ref>). He was arrested twice in England but almost immediately released. Upon entering Scotland, he was arrested several times, the current total being over 20 including [[contempt of court]] after he appeared naked before a judge. His website claimed that ordering him to wear clothes for his court appearance "breached [[European Convention on Human Rights#Article 6 - fair trial|Article 6]] of the [[European Convention on Human Rights]]" – Right to a Fair Trial. He claimed that Articles 3 and 5 to 11 had been repeatedly breached by the authorities since he and Melanie had arrived in Scotland. He served a three-month sentence in Saughton Prison. The walk was resumed on 12 February 2006, and completed shortly after on Monday 20 February the same year. ''The Guardian'' newspaper congratulated the couple on completing their journey, stating that they were practicing [[gymnosophy]] in the tradition of people such as [[George Bernard Shaw]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/feb/21/ruralaffairs.mainsection In praise of... the naked rambler] ''The Guardian'', 21 February 2006. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
Gough was involved with the [[public nudity]] advocacy group The Freedom to be Yourself.<ref>[http://stop-racist-human-skin-phobia.org/ Stop Racist Human Skin Phobia] Steve Gough – Naked Rambler. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
===Six years in prison=== Gough was arrested again on 19 May 2006 at [[Edinburgh Airport]] after removing his clothes during a flight from Southampton to Edinburgh and refusing to get dressed.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/edinburgh_and_east/4994596.stm "Rambler held over mid-air strip"], BBC News, 18 May 2006</ref> On 25 August 2006 he was given a seven-month jail sentence.<ref>[http://news.scotsman.com/topics.cfm?tid=952&id=1260792006 "Nude rambler won't dress despite latest prison term",] ''The Scotsman'', 26 August 2006</ref> On 9 April 2007 Gough was cleared of charges related to his refusal to dress upon being released into Saughton Prison car park in Edinburgh. The ruling judge, Isobel Poole, found that there was no evidence of "actual alarm or disturbance", adding "I can understand this conduct could be considered unpleasant to passers-by had there been any but there is a lack of evidence to that effect."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/edinburgh_and_east/6542329.stm "Naked rambler cleared by sheriff"], BBC News, 10 April 2007</ref> In November 2007, Gough lost his appeal against contempt of court convictions for refusing to wear clothes during his 2005 trial and had another 3 months added to his sentence.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/edinburgh_and_east/7120889.stm |title=Naked rambler jailed for contempt |work=BBC News|date=30 November 2007 |accessdate=6 February 2014}}</ref>
In January 2008, after spending most of the previous 20 months in jail (being rearrested for nudity each time he was released and each time he appeared in court), Gough was released and told that if he went for three months without appearing naked in public he would not be returned to jail for outstanding convictions; two hours later he left the court naked and was immediately re-arrested and subsequently returned to jail.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/edinburgh_and_east/7196711.stm Naked Rambler free for six steps] ''BBC News'', 18 January 2008</ref> Gough served his time in [[Barlinnie Prison]] and was released on 14 October 2008, when he was again immediately arrested for leaving the prison naked. On 14 November, he was cleared of that offence on the grounds of insufficient evidence, but appeared in the dock naked and was rearrested in the foyer of Glasgow Sheriff Court.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/edinburgh_and_east/7730371.stm Naked rambler cleared of breach] BBC News, 14 November 2008</ref> On 18 December he was convicted of a [[breach of the peace]] and sentenced to a further 12 months.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/edinburgh_and_east/7790299.stm "More jail time for naked rambler"], BBC News, 18 December 2008</ref>
In July 2009, Gough, once again standing in the dock naked, was jailed at [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]] for a further 12 months for breach of the peace. Sheriff MacFarlane was told that the bill for dealing with Gough had cost the public an estimated several hundred thousand pounds. The court heard how Gough had finished a previous jail term at Perth Prison and was released to enjoy freedom for the first time in several months. His freedom lasted less than 30 seconds after he walked naked from the prison door to Edinburgh Road. Gough was also sentenced to four months for refusing to dress before the trial.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/tayside_and_central/8154475.stm "Naked rambler is back behind bars"], BBC News, 16 July 2009</ref>
While in jail in Perth, on 6 July 2009, Stephen Gough received a visit from two members of the French ''[[Association pour la promotion du naturisme en liberté]]'' (Association for the Promotion of Naturism in Liberty), which is tracking his activities.<ref>[http://www.apnel.fr/forum/viewtopic.php?id=49 Association pour la promotion du naturisme en liberté] A French forum of Steve Gough supporters. Includes articles written in English.</ref> On 8 February 2010 Gough was convicted of breach of the peace and contempt of court, charges relating to walking naked in Perth and appearing naked in court. He was sentenced to 21 months imprisonment, his longest sentence to date.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/tayside_and_central/8504762.stm "Naked rambler's longest sentence"], BBC News, 8 February 2010</ref>
On 25 November 2010 he was found guilty of: on 26 October 2010, conducting himself in a disorderly manner, standing naked at the gates of Perth Prison, refusing to wear any clothing or otherwise cover his genitals and committing a breach of the peace. He was sentenced to 15 months and 26 days. He is understood to spend his time in prison in [[solitary confinement]].<ref>[http://www.thecourier.co.uk/News/Perthshire/article/8033/naked-rambler-stephen-gough-sent-back-to-prison.html 'Naked rambler' Stephen Gough sent back to prison] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526110509/http://www.thecourier.co.uk/News/Perthshire/article/8033/naked-rambler-stephen-gough-sent-back-to-prison.html |date=26 May 2011 }}, Dundee Courier, 26 November 2010</ref> He was released on 20 July 2011, but immediately rearrested after leaving the prison naked, and received another 657-day sentence.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-tayside-central-14649394|title='Naked rambler' Steven Gough jailed again|author=|date=24 August 2011|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
===From 2012=== When that sentence concluded on 17 July 2012, he left the prison naked again, but this time the police allowed him to go on his way.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-tayside-central-18873631 Naked rambler walks free from Perth Prison] BBC News, Tayside and Central Scotland, 17 July 2012; retrieved 17 July 2012</ref> Three days later, on 20 July, he was rearrested by [[Fife Police]] for a breach of the peace in [[Townhill, Fife|Townhill]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-18931494 Naked rambler Stephen Gough arrested again] BBC News, East Fife, 20 July 2012; retrieved 20 July 2012</ref>
On 13 September 2012 he was sentenced to five months in prison. He had refused to allow social workers to assess his mental health<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/sep/13/naked-rambler-back-to-prison |title=Naked Rambler sent back to prison |work=The Guardian |date=13 September 2012 |accessdate=13 September 2012}}</ref> after he broke down in court during an appearance on 23 August.
Released in early October 2012, he walked from Saughton to [[Edale]], [[Derbyshire]] during October, continuing across the English border down the [[Pennine Way]] to Edale by 31 October, with two arrests en route in [[Hebden Bridge]] and [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]]. Released on bail, he continued to walk south and was due back in Court on 5 February 2013 to face public order charges.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/news/local/updated-rambler-walking-through-halifax-town-centre-naked-this-afternoon-police-arrest-him-for-second-time-1-5063824 |title=UPDATED: Rambler walking through Halifax town centre naked this afternoon – police arrest him for second time |work=Halifax Courier}}</ref> He was arrested in [[Carterton, Oxfordshire|Carterton]], [[Oxfordshire]], on suspicion of outraging public decency on 4 December and was then refused bail and spent Christmas 2012 in jail after his application for bail was refused.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-20808837 Naked rambler Stephen Gough to spend Christmas in jail] BBC News.</ref>
In 2012 Gough won the [[Nicolás Salmerón]] Human Rights Award from the Spanish human rights group, Fundación Internacional de Derechos Humanos.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ene-naturismo.org/revista/premio-nicolas-salmeron-de-derechos-humanos-2012/ |title=Nicolás Salmerón Human Rights Award 2012 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date=2012 |website=ene-naturismo.org |publisher=Asociación de Nudistas Vascos |accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.naturisme.cat/45-news/legislacio/541-stephen-gough-premio-nicolas-salmeron-de-derechos-humanos-2012.html |title=Stephen Gough, Premio Nicolás Salmerón de Derechos Humanos 2012 |author=Joaquim Plana Panella |date=29 November 2012 |website=Club Catala De Naturisme |publisher=Club Catala De Naturisme |accessdate=18 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150721181830/http://www.naturisme.cat/45-news/legislacio/541-stephen-gough-premio-nicolas-salmeron-de-derechos-humanos-2012.html |archivedate=21 July 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lawandreligionuk.com/2014/10/29/public-nudity-as-a-human-right-gough-v-united-kingdom-and-the-echr/ |title=Public nudity as a human right? Gough v United Kingdom and the ECHR |author=Frank Cranmer|date= 29 October 2014|website=Law and Religion UK |publisher=Law and Religion UK |accessdate=18 July 2015}}</ref>
On 19 June 2013 Gough was imprisoned for 11 months for breaching an [[antisocial behaviour order]] (ASBO) on 28 February minutes after it was granted, having recently returned home. Gough was not allowed to appear in court as he refused to wear clothes.<ref name=BBC2013-June-19>{{cite news|title='Naked rambler' Stephen Gough jailed for flouting Asbo|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-22971063|accessdate=19 June 2013|newspaper=BBC News|date=19 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="thej_Thes">{{Cite web | title = The strangest sight in a British courtroom - and I'm not talking about the naked man - The Justice Gap | last = Scheurer | first = Vincent | work = The Justice Gap | date = 13 October 2014 | accessdate = 2015-09-09 | url = http://thejusticegap.com/2014/10/strangest-sight-british-courtroom-im-talking-naked-man/ | language = | quote = }}</ref> In January 2014 he was again jailed for breaching his ASBO this time with a sentence of 16 months .<ref name=bbcjan14>{{cite news |date=6 January 2014 |title='Naked rambler' Stephen Gough jailed for Asbo breach |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-25629531 |newspaper=BBC News |publisher=BBC |accessdate=8 January 2014 }}</ref> On his release from [[Winchester Prison]] he walked out wearing only footwear, once again breaching the ASBO, and in October 2014 he was sentenced to a further two and a half years in prison.<ref>{{cite news|title='Naked rambler' Stephen Gough jailed for Asbo breach|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-29528084|accessdate=8 October 2014|work=BBC News Online}}</ref>
On 28 October 2014, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] ruled that European laws protecting privacy and freedom of expression did not apply to Gough's naked rambling.<ref>{{cite news|title='Naked Rambler' Stephen Gough Loses Legal Battle to Bare All|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/naked-rambler-stephen-gough-loses-legal-battle-bare-all-n235361|accessdate=28 October 2014|work=NBC News (online)}}</ref>
On 14 August 2015 Stephen Gough was released from Winchester prison. At around 6:30am he got into a car inside the prison grounds and was transported from Winchester to Sussex. On his release from prison, ''[[The Sunday Times]]'', described him as a previous 'prisoner of conscience.'<ref name=SundayTimes-1593666>{{cite news|title=Even a return to solitary won't stop me wandering as nature intended|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/newsreview/features/article1593666.ece|author=Alev Scott|date=16 August 2015|work=[[The Sunday Times]]|accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref>
[[Daniel Finkelstein]] wrote about Gough and his practice of unlimited naturism in ''[[The Times]]'' just before Christmas 2015:
{{quote|Our standards of modesty and decency have changed so much and so rapidly that it is hard to believe that they won't change further, making complete nudity perfectly normal. In anticipating this, Stephen Gough is not dotty, he is just slightly ahead of the rest of us. And when he puts his case to be allowed his nudity, it is hard to resist. The rest of us are the dotty ones, insisting upon dress for which there frankly isn't a reasonable argument. Yet he should still go to jail.<ref name="Finkelstein">{{cite news|last=Finkelstein|first=Daniel|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/opinion/columnists/article4648118.ece|title=The naked truth is this man must be locked up|work=The Times|location=London|date=23 December 2015|accessdate=23 December 2015}} {{subscription required}}</ref>}}
In Finkelstein's opinion: "The refusal of individuals to abide by court rulings is deeply injurious to a free society based upon law, and we have to protect ourselves against it."<ref name="Finkelstein"/>
===''Who Bares Wins''=== A comedic theatrical production invoking Gough's initial naked ramble of 2003–2004 titled ''Who Bares Wins'' was produced by Scottish theatre company Right Lines Productions in 2004. The play, written by Euan Martin and Dave Smith and directed by Mark Saunders, followed the Rambler on his journey through the Scottish countryside and his numerous stints in Scottish prisons.
Set against the backdrop of a remote community eagerly awaiting the arrival of the Rambler for its own reasons, ''Who Bares Wins'' explores society's wide range of attitudes to nudity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rightlines.net/rightlines/sample-page/who-bares-wins-2/|title=Who Bares Wins|author=|date=|website=Right Lines Productions|accessdate=1 November 2017}}</ref> The play, starring Ron Emslie and [[Alyth McCormack]], toured Scotland and was seen by Gough himself, without clothes on, at The Universal Hall, [[Findhorn Foundation|Findhorn]], in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://northings.com/2007/09/01/hitn-profile-right-lines-productions/|title=HITN Profile: Right Lines Productions|author=|date=1 September 2007|website=Northings|accessdate=1 November 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Andrew Martinez]] *[[Clothes free organizations]] *[[Naked hiking]] *[[Naturism]] and [[Nudism]] *[[Streaking]] *[[Timeline of significant non-sexualized public nudity activities]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group |group = '''Tau Taa Wana people'''
'''Tau Ta'a Wana / Wana / Tao Taa Wana / To Wana''' |image = |caption = |poptime = |popplace = {{flag|Indonesia}} ([[Central Sulawesi]]) |langs = [[Pamona language]] (Waa dialect), [[Indonesian language]] |rels = [[Ancestral worship]] (predominantly), [[Christianity]], [[Islam]] |related = [[Pamona people]] }} The '''Tau Taa Wana''' (sometimes '''Tau Ta'a Wana''' or '''Tao Taa Wana''') is a sub-group of the numerous people who speak variants of the Ta'a or [[Pamona language]] of Eastern [[Central Sulawesi]], [[Indonesia]].http://www.forestpeoples.org/documents/asia_pacific/indonesia_wana_visit_mc_mar09_eng.pdf{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} The Tau Taa Wana people referred to themselves as '''Tao Taa''', as in ''tao'' means "people" and ''taa'' means "not". But most outsiders refers them as '''To Wana''' which means "people in the forest" because of their social image as a community residing in forests.{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/4669620/Ethnoecological_System_of_Tao_Taa_Wana_In_the_Morowali_Nature_Reserve_Central_Sulawesi_Indonesia |title=Ethnoecological System of Tao Taa Wana Tribe In The Morowali Nature Reserve, Central Sulawesi, Indonesia |author=Ramadhanil Pitopang |year=2012 |publisher=academia.edu |accessdate=2014-10-08}} The Tau Taa Wana people are an [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous tribe]] who live in small villages or ''lipu's'' around the Bulang and [[Bongka River]]. Since the year 2000, the Wana have implemented rotational farming as a means of maintaining themselves. Before this they lived as a [[nomadic tribe]].Jane Monnig Atkinson, 1989, The Art and Politics of Wana Shamanship, University of California Press, Berkeley. The Tau Taa Wana are currently under threat. This is mainly constituted over land trouble. Since 1994 incursions from the government of Indonesia's [[Transmigration operation|transmigration]] program have affected their traditional ways of life.http://www.forestpeoples.org/documents/asia_pacific/indonesia_wana_visit_mc_mar09_eng.pdf{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} ''[[Yayasan Merah Putih]]'' is a [[non-profit]], [[NGO]] in [[Palu]] that has been a supporter of Wana rights since 1999 and has also introduced ''sekolah lipu's'' or village schools in order to help the Tau Taa Wana community.http://www.ymp.or.id/ == References == {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{Citation | author=Marcus Colchester | title=A Visit To The Land Of The Wana: A Forest People Of Indonesia | url=http://www.forestpeoples.org/sites/fpp/files/publication/2010/08/indonesiawanavisitmcmar09eng.pdf | publication-date=2009 | publisher=[[Forest Peoples Programme]] }} ==External links== * [http://www.ymp.or.id/english/ http://www.ymp.or.id/english/ Official website in English ] {{Ethnic groups in Indonesia}} {{Portal|Indonesia}} [[Category:Central Sulawesi]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Indonesia]] {{Indonesia-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{notability|date=August 2009}} {{underlinked|date=October 2012}} {{citation style|date=August 2009}} {{essay|date=August 2009}} {{undue weight|date=January 2018}} {{lead too short|date=January 2018}} }}
'''Team conflict''' is [[Organizational conflict|conflict]] within a [[team]].
== Causes == Conflicts may be caused by differing goals, values or perceptions of the team members.<ref>{{citation|author=Tony Alessandra, Phil Hunsaker |year=1993 |title=Communicating at Work |publisher=Fireside Publishers |page=92}}</ref>
=== "Faultlines" in groups === Lau and Murnighan identify what they call "faultlines" as a source of conflicts within groups.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Lau|first=Dora C.|last2=Murnighan|first2=J. Keith|date=1998|title=Demographic Diversity and Faultines: The Compositional Dynamics of Organizational Groups|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Dora_Lau/publication/259461922_Demographic_Diversity_and_Faultlines_The_Compositional_Dynamics_of_Organizational_Groups/links/0c96052bd053167cd5000000.pdf|volume=23|issue=2|pages=325–340}}</ref> As a supplement to traditional approaches of research that focused on diversity characterized by variance of demographic attributes across a population,<ref>{{Cite book|title=Inequality and composition: A primitive theory of social structure.|last=Blau|first=P. M.|publisher=|year=1977|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=O'Reilly|first=Charles A.|last2=Caldwell|first2=David F.|last3=Barnett|first3=William P.|date=1989-01-01|title=Work Group Demography, Social Integration, and Turnover|journal=Administrative Science Quarterly|volume=34|issue=1|pages=21–37|doi=10.2307/2392984|jstor=2392984}}</ref> faultlines are hypothetical dividing lines that split groups into multiple sets of subgroups with each set based on different attributes. These attributes may be [[Demography|demographics]], but also may be characteristics such as personal values or personalities. This work builds on work in [[social identity theory]] and [[self-categorization theory]], which explains the ways in which individuals favor other individuals with whom they share a common identity;<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hogg|first=Michael A.|last2=Terry|first2=Deborah I.|date=2000-01-01|title=Social Identity and Self-Categorization Processes in Organizational Contexts|url=http://amr.aom.org/content/25/1/121|journal=Academy of Management Review|language=en|volume=25|issue=1|pages=121–140|doi=10.5465/AMR.2000.2791606|issn=0363-7425}}</ref> per this model, individuals evaluate members of their subgroups more positively than other members of the larger group, which may lead to conflict when disagreements occur across faultlines. Lau and Murnighan identify three compositional factors for faultlines within a group: # The number of individual attributes apparent to group members # Their alignment # The number of potentially homogenous subgroups A group has weak faultlines if subgroups contain different members across sets, and strong faultlines if group members fall in the same groups across sets. For example, a team composed half of young male entry-level employees and half of older female executives has strong faultlines because each member falls in subgroups with the same other members across all three demographic characteristics.<ref name=":0" />
Subsequent work on the impact of these embedded subgroups, called "factions" when overlap in subgroups is structured into teams, has found significant negative impacts on group productivity stemming from task conflict, emotional conflict, and behavioral disintegration.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Li|first=Jiatao|last2=Hambrick|first2=Donald C.|date=2005-10-01|title=Factional Groups: A New Vantage on Demographic Faultlines, Conflict, and Disintegration in Work Teams|url=http://amj.aom.org/content/48/5/794|journal=Academy of Management Journal|language=en|volume=48|issue=5|pages=794–813|doi=10.5465/AMJ.2005.18803923|issn=0001-4273}}</ref> Faultlines were found to better predict variance in a variety of group self-perception metrics than traditional metrics of group heterogeneity, including perceptions of team-learning, psychological safety, satisfaction, and expected performance.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lau|first=Dora C.|last2=Murnighan|first2=J. Keith|date=2005-08-01|title=Interactions Within Groups and Subgroups: The Effects of Demographic Faultlines|url=http://amj.aom.org/content/48/4/645|journal=Academy of Management Journal|language=en|volume=48|issue=4|pages=645–659|doi=10.5465/AMJ.2005.17843943|issn=0001-4273}}</ref>
It is important to note that, while the concept of faultlines model may be seen as presenting diversity as a challenge to be overcome, diversity has been found to contribute significantly to team outcomes under certain circumstances.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0065-2601(08)60133-1|title=Toward A Theory of Conversion Behavior|last=Moscovici|first=Serge|pages=209–239|language=en|doi=10.1016/s0065-2601(08)60133-1}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Minority Influence|last=Muscovici|first=S.|publisher=Nelson-Hall Publishers|year=1994|isbn=|editor1=Muscovici, S.|editor2=Mucchi-Faina, A.|editor3=Maass, A.|location=Chicago|pages=233–251|chapter=Three concepts: Minority, conflict, and behavioral-style}}</ref> Respectful inclusion of the opinions of minority members can lead to increased creativity as the group incorporates their distinct perspectives.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jehn|first=Karen A.|date=1995-01-01|title=A Multimethod Examination of the Benefits and Detriments of Intragroup Conflict|journal=Administrative Science Quarterly|volume=40|issue=2|pages=256–282|doi=10.2307/2393638|jstor=2393638}}</ref> The challenges associated with inclusivity are not insubstantial, and may require strong [[leadership]] and norms of tolerance and respect to overcome.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alderfer|first=Clayton P.|date=1991-06-01|title=Changing Race Relations in Organizations: A Critique of the Contact Hypothesis|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1936-4490.1991.tb00547.x/abstract|journal=Canadian Journal of Administrative Sciences / Revue Canadienne des Sciences de l'Administration|language=en|volume=8|issue=2|pages=80–88|doi=10.1111/j.1936-4490.1991.tb00547.x|issn=1936-4490}}</ref>
== Types of conflicts == "Hot conflicts"{{explain|date=January 2018}} have three common symptoms: * Team members persist in arguing the same points. * When the team reaches impasse, talks gets personal. Accusations may be spoken out loud, and members may speculate privately about one another’s motives. * Once negative attributions take hold, emotions flare and progress halts.
Allen C. Amason, of Mississippi State University, studied conflict and its role in decision-making. He stated that there are two kinds of conflict: cognitive — conflict based upon issues, ideas, processes or principles — and affective — conflict based upon personalities, emotions or values.
Researcher Thomas K. Capozzoli (1995) classified conflicts by whether the outcome was constructive or destructive. Conflicts are constructive when people change and grow personally from the conflict; the conflict results in a solution to a problem; the involvement of everyone affected by the conflict is increased; the team becomes more cohesive. Conflicts are destructive when no decision is reached and problem still exists; energy is diverted away from productive activities; the morale of the team members goes down; the team becomes divided.
=== Workplace conflict === {{Main|Workplace conflict}} Team conflict is common in the workplace where it may hinder productivity and the achievement of team goals. If management of conflict is not effective, it can disrupt group processes, but successfully-managed conflict may benefit the group.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Organizational Behavior|last=George|first=J. M.|last2=Jones|first2=G. R.|publisher=Prentice Hall|year=2005|isbn=|location=New York|pages=418}}</ref>
== Six-step procedure for dealing with conflict in teams == Conflict is a normal part of working in teams, because it brings creativity and helps avoid [[groupthink]]. However, too much conflict can stop teams for doing their work and certain procedures should be followed to get back on track. Guffey, Rhodes, and Rogin describe their six-step process for dealing with conflict in teams:<ref>Guffey, Mary Ellen, Kathleen Rhodes and Patricia Rogin. "Business Communication: Process and Product." Toronto: Thomson South-Western, 2010. Print.</ref> # Listen: In order for everyone to understand the problem. # Understand the other's point of view: Listening makes understanding the other's position easier. Show this by asking questions. # Show a concern for the relationship: Focus on the problem, not the person. Show that his or her needs are cared for and an overall willingness to resolve the conflict. # Look for common ground: Identify both sides' interest and see what you have in common. # Invent new problem-solving options: Brainstorm on new ways to solve the conflict and be sure to be open to new suggestions. # Reach an agreement on what's fair: Find a middle ground of whats fair and choose the best options after weighing the possible solutions.
== References == {{Reflist}} {{refbegin}} * Alessandra, Tony Ph.D. & Hunsaker, Phil Ph.D. (1993) Communicating at Work. New York: Fireside Publishers. * Cappozzoli, Thomas K. (1995, Dec). Resolving conflict within teams. Journal for Quality and Participation. v18n7, p. 28-30. * "Resolve Hot Topics with Cooler Heads." Negotiation (May 2007): 12-12. {{refend}}
[[Category:Teams]] [[Category:Interpersonal conflict]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Use British English|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = The Gypsy and the Gentleman | image_size = | image = The Gypsy and the Gentleman FilmPoster.jpeg | caption = | producer = Maurice Cowan | director = [[Joseph Losey]] | screenplay = [[Janet Green (screenwriter)|Janet Green]] | based on = novel ''Darkness I Leave You'' by Nina Warner Hooks | starring = [[Melina Mercouri]]
[[Keith Michell]]
[[Flora Robson]] | music = [[Hans May]] | cinematography = [[Jack Hildyard]] | editing = [[Reginald Beck]] | studio = [[The Rank Organisation]] | distributor = Rank Film Distributors | released = {{Film date|df=y|1958|01|15|London,UK}} | runtime = 103 min. | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = | amg_id = }} '''''The Gypsy and the Gentleman''''' is a 1958 British [[costume drama]] film directed by [[Joseph Losey]]. It stars [[Melina Mercouri]] and [[Keith Michell]].{{cite web|url=http://allmovie.com/work/the-gypsy-and-the-gentleman-94123|title=The Gypsy and the Gentleman (1958) - Joseph Losey - Synopsis, Characteristics, Moods, Themes and Related - AllMovie|website=AllMovie}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b6abb134d|title=The Gypsy and the Gentleman (1958)|publisher=}} ==Plot== The beautiful and fiery gypsy Belle (Melina Mercouri) marries Regency playboy Sir Paul Deverill (Keith Michell) for his money. Unbeknownst to her he has squandered his fortune and is desperately in debt. When Deverill's sister Sarah (June Laverick) inherits a fortune, the couple's frustrated plots to steal it from her lead to their eventual demise. ==Cast== * [[Melina Mercouri]] as Belle * [[Keith Michell]] as Sir Paul Deverill * [[Flora Robson]] as Mrs. Haggard * [[Patrick McGoohan]] as Jess * [[June Laverick]] as Sarah Deverill * [[Lyndon Brook]] as John Patterson * [[Helen Haye]] as Lady Caroline Ayrton * [[Mervyn Johns]] as Brook * [[Laurence Naismith]] as Dr. Forrester * Clare Austin as Vanessa Ruddock * [[Catherine Feller]] as Hattie * [[Nigel Green]] as Game Pup * Newton Blick as Ruddock * David Hart as Will the Valet * [[John Salew]] as Duffin the Butler ==Critical reception== Derek Winnert wrote, "The movie is hardly director Losey’s usual cup of tea, but he tries to get some bite into the gold-digger themes and the 18th century rural England period setting. And the whirlwind Mercouri acts up a storm, certainly ringing that Belle loud and clear."{{cite web|url=http://www.derekwinnert.com/the-gypsy-and-the-gentlemen-1958-melina-mercouri-keith-michell-flora-robson-classic-movie-review-5848/|title=The Gypsy and the Gentlemen *** (1958, Melina Mercouri, Keith Michell, Flora Robson, Patrick McGoohan, June Laverick, Helen Haye, Lyndon Brook) – Classic Movie Review 5848 - Derek Winnert|website=www.derekwinnert.com}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{imdb title|id=0051692|title=The Gypsy and the Gentleman}} {{Joseph Losey}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gypsy and the Gentleman, The}} [[Category:1958 films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:Films directed by Joseph Losey]] [[Category:Films shot at Pinewood Studios]] [[Category:British historical films]] [[Category:1950s historical films]] [[Category:Fictional representations of Romani people]] {{historic-film-stub}}

<!-- EDIT BELOW THIS LINE --> '''UK Dating Awards''', shortened to the UKDAs, are annual awards given for excellence in the British dating industry. The UKDAs were first conferred in 2014.<ref>Edmunds, Simon [http://globaldatinginsights.com/11092014-uk-dating-awards-seeks-to-bring-industry-together/ “UK Dating Awards Seeks to Bring Industry Together”] Global Dating Insights</ref>
The nominations in each category are generated by self-entry. Entries are then shortlisted, and winners voted on by a panel of industry experts. Certain categories are voted for in a public vote.<ref>Edmunds, Simon [http://globaldatinginsights.com/11092014-uk-dating-awards-seeks-to-bring-industry-together/ “UK Dating Awards Seeks to Bring Industry Together”] Global Dating Insights</ref>
The Awards are presented at a ceremony at Armoury House in North London.<ref>Bye, Samantha [http://metro.co.uk/2015/12/02/10-things-you-need-to-know-about-the-future-of-dating-5539135/ “10 things you need to know about the future of dating”] Metro</ref> They are supported by the Online Dating Association.<ref>[http://www.onlinedatingassociation.org.uk/news/news.celebrating-the-uk-dating-awards.html “Celebrating the UK Dating Awards”] Online Dating Association</ref>
The Awards were created by Charly Lester, a dating blogger, journalist and former Global Head of Dating for [[Time Out Group|Time Out media group]].<ref>Edmonds, Lizzie [https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/michelin-stars-for-the-best-online-dating-sites-9744170.html “Michelin stars for the best online dating sites”] Evening Standard</ref> In 2015 Lester announced the creation of complementary US Dating Awards and European Dating Awards,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://globaldatinginsights.com/2016/03/16/standard-entries-for-first-european-dating-awards-close-this-friday/|title=Standard Entries For First Ever European Dating Awards Close This Friday|website=Global Dating Insights|access-date=2016-03-16}}</ref> both of which launched in 2016.
==Winners==
===2016=== *Best Customer Service - Drawing Down the Moon Matchmaking *Online Dating Brand of the Year - [[The Inner Circle (dating site)|The Inner Circle]] *Daters' Favourite Dating Site - [[Christian Connection (website)|Christian Connection]] *Dating App of the Year - Hinge *Best New Dating Brand - ooOo *Dating Expert of the Year - Jo Hemmings *Matchmaking Agency of the Year - Simantov International *Upcoming Matchmaker of the Year - Soiree Society NI *Dating Writer of the Year - Stella Grey *ioSquare Innovation Within the Industry - Good Deed Dating *Best Dating-Related Marketing Campaign - TrueView *Scamalytics Safer Dating Award - TrueView *Best Niche Dating Brand - [[Christian Connection (website)|Christian Connection]] *Best Use of Social Media - [[Lovestruck.com]] *Matchmaker Academy Best New Dating Individual - Ane Auret *Dating Events Brand of the Year - Smudged Lipstick *Dating Ink Dating Blogger of the Year - Naomi Lewis *Best Commercial Dating Blog - [[Cupid.com]] *Best Dating TV Show - [[First Dates]] *Founder's Award - George Kidd
===2015=== *Founder’s Award – For 30 Years Service to the Industry – Mary Balfour, Drawing Down the Moon <ref>Edmunds, Simon [http://globaldatinginsights.com/27112015-here-is-the-full-list-of-uk-dating-award-winners/ “Here is the Full List of UK Dating Award Winners 2015”] Global Dating Insights</ref><ref>Edmunds, Simon [http://globaldatinginsights.com/27112015-christian-connection-lovestruck-big-winners-at-uk-dating-awards-2015/ “Christian Connection & Lovestruck Big Winners at UK Dating Awards”] Global Dating Insights</ref> *Online Dating Brand of the Year – [[Lovestruck.com]] *Daters’ Favourite Dating Site – Christian Connection *Dating Writer of the Year – Daisy Buchanan *Dating Expert of the Year – Susan Quilliam *Dating Entrepreneur of the Year – Turn Partners *Best Newcomer Individual – Tara McDonnell *Blogger of the Year – Jordi Sinclair, 30 Something London *Best New Dating Site – Bristlr *Best New Dating App – Clocked *Matchmaking Agency of the Year – Drawing Down the Moon *Best Niche Dating Site –[[Christian Connection (website)|Christian Connection]] *Best White Label Dating Site – We Love Dates *Dating Events Brand of the Year – The Inner Circle *Most Original Dating Event – Playdate *Innovation in the Dating Industry – TrueView *Safer Dating – Venntro *Best Dating-Related Marketing Campaign – [[Match.com]] *Best Commercial Dating Blog – Toyboy Warehouse *Best Customer Service – Guardian Soulmates
===2014=== *Dating Website of the Year – [[Lovestruck.com]]<ref>Edmunds, Simon [http://globaldatinginsights.com/14112014-lovestruck-and-guardian-soulmates-win-top-prizes-at-uk-dating-awards/ “Lovestruck and Guardian Soulmates win top prizes at UK Dating Awards”] Global Dating Insights</ref><ref>Brealey, Caroline [http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/caroline-brealey/uk-dating-awards-2014_b_6274600.html “A Fantastic Night : The UK Dating Awards 2014”] Huffington Post</ref> *Best Newcomer Dating App – TrueView *Daters’ Favourite Dating Site – ''[[The Guardian]]'' Soulmates *Best Religious Dating Site – [[Christian Connection (website)|Christian Connection]] *Dating App of the Year – [[Lovestruck.com]] *Best Newcomer Dating Website – [[The Inner Circle (dating site)|The Inner Circle]] *Best Niche Dating Site – Muddy Matches *Matchmaker of the Year – Caroline Brealey, Mutual Attraction *Blogger of the Year – Katy Horwood, All Sweetness and Life *Dating Journalist of the Year – Andy Jones *Dating Expert of the Year – Jo Hemmings *Dating Entrepreneur of the Year – Turn Partners *Best New Dating Individual – Saskia Nelson *Dating Column of the Year – Tom Craine, ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'' *Dating Blog of the Year – All Sweetness and Life *Best New Dating Blog – Urban Social - UrbanSocial *Dating TV Show of the Year – [[First Dates]] *Best Magazine for Dating – Cosmopolitan - ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'' *Best Dating-Related Marketing Campaign – ''[[The Guardian]]'' Soulmates *Safer Dating Award – Scamalytics *Best London Dating Event – The Inner Circle *Best Speed Dating Event – Date in a Dash *Best Food or Drink Event – Table8 *Most Original Dating Event – Loveflutter *Best Singles Party – [[Lovestruck.com]] *Founder’s Award – Trailblazer of the Year – [[tinder (app)|tinder]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *[http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/14112248.The_Boys_and_The_Bees__My_night_at_The_UK_Dating_Awards/ ''The Herald'']
==External links== *{{Official website| https://ukdatingawards.com/}}
[[Category:British awards]] [[Category:Dating]]

revision.text:
{{Expand Spanish|Inmigración uruguaya en México|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group = Uruguayan Mexicans
''uruguayo-mexicanos'' |image= |caption= |population = '''3,023''' Uruguay-born residents (2017){{cite web|title=Table 1: Total migrant stock at mid-year by origin and by major area, region, country or area of destination, 2017|url=http://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/migration/data/estimates2/data/UN_MigrantStockByOriginAndDestination_2017.xlsx|publisher=United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division |accessdate=17 August 2018}} Unknown number of Mexicans of Uruguayan descent |rels= [[Roman Catholicism]] |related = [[Uruguayan diaspora]], [[Argentine Mexican]]s }} '''Uruguayan Mexicans''' are people born in [[Uruguay]] who live in [[Mexico]], or Mexican-born people of Uruguayan descent. == Overview == There are lots of Uruguayan-born persons living in Mexico, for a number of reasons. Both countries share the [[Spanish language]]; the historical origins of both nations is common (part of the [[Spanish Empire]] until the early 19th century); Mexico has a much bigger economy, which attracted Uruguayans in search of opportunities; and, from the political point of view, during the [[civic-military dictatorship of Uruguay]] (1973-1985), ideological affinity made Mexico attractive as an exile destination for several Uruguayans. Uruguayan residents in Mexico have their own institutions, for instance, the Consultative Councils in [[Mexico City]], [[Cancun]], [[Puebla]], and [[Toluca]].{{cite web |url=http://www.d20.org.uy/Lista-de-Consejos |title=List of Consultative Councils of Uruguayans abroad |accessdate=1 November 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130809011138/http://www.d20.org.uy/Lista-de-Consejos |archive-date=9 August 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} {{es icon}} ==Notable people== ;past *[[Alejandro Zaffaroni]] (1923-2014), serial entrepreneur in the biotechnological field *[[Alfredo Zitarrosa]] (1936-1984), singer-songwriter ;present *[[Pietro Ameglio]] (born 1958 in Uruguay), civil rights and peace activist *[[Marcelo Buquet]] (born 1963 in Montevideo), actor and model *[[Nery Castillo]] (born 1984 in San Luis Potosí), footballer who started his career in Uruguay *[[Edgardo Codesal]] (born 1951 in Montevideo), football referee *[[Carlos Miloc]] (born 1932 in Montevideo), football coach *[[Bárbara Mori]] (born 1978 in Montevideo), actress *[[Kenya Mori]] (born 1976 in Mexico City), actress *[[Rodrigo Plá]] (born 1968 in Montevideo), screenwriter and film director ==See also== *[[Mexico–Uruguay relations]] *[[Mexicans in Uruguay]] *[[Immigration to Mexico]] ==References== {{reflist}} == Further reading == * [http://www.derecho.unam.mx/investigacion/publicaciones/coediciones/pdf-coediciones/Exilio-Urugayo.pdf El exilio uruguayo en México] {{Uruguayan diaspora}} {{Ethnic groups in Mexico}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Mexico]] [[Category:Mexican people of Uruguayan descent| ]] [[Category:Uruguayan diaspora|Mexico]] {{Uruguay-hist-stub}} {{Mexico-hist-stub}}

{{Infobox Instrument |name=Šargija |names= |image= Sargija.svg |classification= *[[Plucked string instrument]]s |range= |related= * [[Bouzouki]] ([[Greece]]) * [[Buzuq]] ([[Lebanon]]) * [[Tambouras]] * [[Tambura (instrument)|Tambura]] * [[Baglama]] * [[Baglamas]] * [[Dangubica]] }} The '''šargija''' ([[Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic]]: Шаргија, {{lang-sq| Sharki}}) is a [[Plucked string instrument|plucked]], [[fret]]ted long necked [[chordophone]] used in the [[folk music]] of various [[Balkans|Balkan]] countries, including [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Croatia]], [[Albania]], and [[Serbia]].
The šargija originated in Bosnia and Herzegovina during the rule of [[Ottoman Empire]], and is played by [[Bosniaks]], [[Albanians]], [[Serbs]] and [[Croats]]. Its original four strings have been increased to six or even seven. The šargija usually accompanies the [[violin]], and has a jangling sound, similar to the Turkish [[baglama|saz]]. The sharki (or sargija) is a similar instrument as the two-string qiftelia, but with more strings and looking more like a primitive saz. Spelling is sometimes: sarkia or sharki or sharkia. Usually there are three courses of metal strings. The frets are often inlaid metal frets, in a non-western pattern. Body could be made from separate staves, or carved from one piece of wood.
==Use== The šargija is used by the [[Bosnians]] in [[Bosnian root music]]. The [[tamburica]]/[[Tambura (instrument)|tambura]] is mostly associated with Croats and some Serbs.
==Sources== {{no footnotes|date=June 2012}} *[http://www.atlasofpluckedinstruments.com/europe3.htm Atlas of Plucked Instruments] *[http://jazz.sdsu.edu/courseM151/weeks11-15/Eastern_Europe.htm JazzStudied Website] — San Diego State University
